issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
The user console won't function on some older browsers, but it fails to warn the user if they attempt to use a browser that is too old.

3.4 used this message:

unsupported_browser = The browser version you are using is not supported, and may result in unpredictable behavior or incomplete functionality. To use the Eucalyptus Management Console you should be running one of the following browsers (minimum required version): Chrome 22, Firefox 15, Safari 6, or IE 9.


Which we should update, but that's the general message.
fields.summary: Console fails to warn user if they are using an unsupported browser

comments.body:
[~kgill] [~viglesias] [~alice]
I'm unsure on some browser versions. I know we support IE 10 and higher. Safari 6 still sounds good (I have 6.12 on my MBP). Chrome is currently at 33.0 and I put 30 in the warning. Firefox is at 28, so I put 25 in the warning. Those last 2 are pretty arbitrary and having more concrete numbers would be good. After I get the warnings in place, I'll go back to verify what our dependencies require and update the checks/warning.
Thinking more about this, using modernizr, we ought to simply look for features we need and let missing features trigger the warning (if we even keep that the same)

trying to come up with a list of features to test for. some educated guesses here:

 - localStorage
 - SVG

anything else??? There are a bunch of css things listed, but I suspect we aren't pushing the boundaries of css in this go-round.

Instead of warning about browser version, warning if the browser they use doesn't support features we require. I've been unable to test so far, but I think this type verification is where things are headed (note modernizr library). This way, we don't have to keep updating our checks for new browsers and as we deprecate testing of older ones.
passing to you for testing, alice...i have no way to look at this. Thanks!
tested on Opera version 20.0.1387.91 got no warning message
We don't warn on browser version anymore. We warn on feature support per discussion here.

[~jloza] Recent versions of Opera are webkit-based, which should work since we test on other webkit-based browsers (e.g. Safari).  

Feature detection, not browser detection, is the Web standard for modern apps.

References:
http://www.html5rocks.com/en/tutorials/detection/
http://learn.jquery.com/code-organization/feature-browser-detection/
http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/hh273397(v=vs.85).aspx

[~dkavanagh] and [~kgill], I was just looking for some kind of message, any message, unsupported features or anything,  and didn't see anything...didn't know Opera was supported (we should add it to our compatibility matrix if that's the case). 

Thanks...

As Kamal said, this is a trend in web applications. Not having a hard and fast list of browsers we support with the associated warning should improve UX overall by not warning them about browsers we haven't tested against. Us not testing on that browser is not guarantee of failure. The warning has been a pain to maintain since we need to continuously change this. It also can warn users needlessly. Since we're adhering to standards and using libraries like jquery which help factor out minor differences, we should generally work well on many browsers on many platforms.

so, I'm not sure we would really have a "compatibility matrix" per-se, but we could list ones we've tried in addition to ones we've actually done testing with.
[~dkavanagh], [~kgill]: Is there a warning that displays for unsupported features? The comments on this ticket make it seem that there is. If so, how can I test it?

Yes, we have 1 for SVG "The browser you are using is not supported. It lacks support for SVG images and many graphics this application uses won't display properly."

I'm not sure how to find a browser that doesn't have that. I've looked at some browser feature matrix listings I found via google and it might just be fairly old browsers at this point.

I just added GUI-800 for another feature test we *should* be doing.
I just found that as well! Useful site!
